title: Data Sources
text:
This table summarizes commonly used data sources for population health, health services, and social science research at BU. It includes administrative claims, EHR, survey, and public health datasets.
Some of the resources are publicly available ( public ), while others require special credentials ( private ).

title: Staff
text:
Our staff bring expertise across data science, public health, EHR systems, and advanced analytics. Email us at bedacprp@bu.edu to get started!



  
    
    
      Joseph Palmisano
      Director, Data Hub
      Joseph's team at the Biostatistics and Epidemiology Data Analytics Center (BEDAC) specializes in data management, database and web programming, and sophisticated statistical analysis in support of a wide range of research initiatives.
    
  





  
    
    
      Emily Sisson
      Director, Data Hub
      Emily's leadership at the Biostatistics and Epidemiology Data Analytics Center (BEDAC), involves leading diverse teams and optimizing research operations andstrategic growth.
    
  





  
    
    
      Dr. Nina Cesare
      Assisant Director, Data Hub
      Nina's work bridges data science and sociology, using digital and spatial data to explore social determinants of health and the methodological challenges of modern social research
    
  





  
    
    
      Dr. Chad Milando
      Assistant Director, Data Hub
      Chad supports faculty with data sourcing and analytic strategy. His research focuses on environmental health and spatiotemporal modeling.

title: Welcome
text:
The Center for Health Data Sciences Data Hub is a university-wide collaborataive resource designed to help faculty and staff navigate the fast-moving world of data science, machine learning, and AI. Whether you’re just getting started or exploring advanced analytic strategies, the Data Hub is your first stop for expert advice.




What We Offer
Our team of data specialists can help researchers:

Discover and evaluate relevant data sources.
Learn about research environments available at BU
Provide feedback on research design
Facilitate collaboration across BU

These 30-minute sessions are offered at no cost and are open to faculty and staff across BU.





How It Works

Submit a Request: Email us at BEDAC Proposals
We’ll Schedule a Session: A data expert will then reach out and schedule a meeting.
Get Connected: If your request needs more follow-up, we’ll refer you to the right partner in CHDS, BEDAC, or beyond







Topics We Cover
Our team can help with questions related to:

Sourcing internal and external datasets
Data licensing and permissions
IRB and data use agreements (DUAs)
Matching your research question to the right method or tool
Building collaborations across BU






Strategic Benefits
The Data Hub enables health research at BU to reach its full potential. The Hub helps:

Break down silos across schools and research centers
Strengthen proposals by improving data and methodology plans
Save time, letting investigators focus on analysis instead of logistics





The BU Data Hub is powered by CHDS and BEDAC at the BU School of Public Health, with support from research and IT partners across the university.

title: NIH All of Us Research Program
text:
All of Us is a comprehensive diverse health database that collects comprehensive genetic, environmental, and lifestyle information from one million or more U.S. participants to advance precision medicine. The target sample includes 1 million or more US participants designed to reflect the diversity of the U.S. population. Study design focuses on groups historically underrepresented in biomedical research. There are currently over 600,000 participants enrolled who provide valuable data across several domains: surveys, electronic health records, physical measurements, wearables, genomics, and biosamples. This project emphasizes equitable research practices, collaboration and transparency across the research process.


Data Dictionary, Metadata, Years Available

Years Available: Initiated in 2018; current release covers 2019-2023.
Population: A diverse sample of individuals, with emphasis on those historically underrepresented in biomedical research.
Geography: United States, down to 3 digit zip code.
Unit of analysis: Individual
Documentation:

Visit the All of Us Data Browser: https://databrowser.researchallofus.org/
Learn more about the All of Us Research Hub: https://www.researchallofus.org/about-the-research-hub/




Data Use Agreement

Researchers at BU have access to the Controlled Tier, which includes genomic information.
All Research Workbench users must complete All of Us registration and training: https://www.researchallofus.org/register/



Common Use Cases

Precision medicine research integrating genomics, clinical data, and lifestyle information.
Population health studies focusing on diverse groups and health disparities. Epidemiological investigations of specific diseases or conditions.
For more information, browse the research project directory: https://www.researchallofus.org/research-project-directory/



Related Publications

Explore the All of Us Publication Directory: https://www.researchallofus.org/publication-directory/

title: Framingham Heart Study (FHS)
text:
The Framingham Heart Study is one of the most influential and longest-running epidemiologic cohort studies in the world. Established by the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI) in 1948 in Framingham, Massachusetts, the study follows multiple generations of participants to understand the determinants of cardiovascular disease and related chronic conditions. Over time, FHS has expanded to include the Original Cohort, Offspring Cohort, and Third Generation Cohort, along with focused ancillary studies.
FHS collects exceptionally rich, longitudinal data on participants, including repeated clinical examinations, lifestyle and behavioral measures, medication use, imaging, genomics, biomarkers, and detailed cardiovascular outcomes. Its multi-decade follow-up structure makes it uniquely suited for studying disease risk trajectories, early-life predictors of later-life health, gene–environment interactions, and the natural history of cardiometabolic conditions.
The study has played a foundational role in identifying major cardiovascular risk factors—such as hypertension, hyperlipidemia, smoking, diabetes, and obesity—and continues to serve as a critical scientific resource for contemporary research on aging, cardiovascular health, neurocognitive decline, and precision medicine. Data access is available to approved researchers through controlled mechanisms managed by NHLBI.


Data Dictionary, Metadata, Years Available

Years Available:
Geography:
Population:
Documentation:
Tutorial from BU Libraries:



How to access
Reach out to bedacprp@bu.edu


Related Publications

title: ACS
text:
The American Community Survey (ACS) is an annual, nationally representative survey that collects detailed information on residents’ demographic characteristics, housing status, education, transportation habits, employment, and more. Approximately 3.5 million residents are sampled each year. Data are organized by topic-specific tables, cover a variety of geographies (from national to Census Block Group) and offered as 1-year or 5-year estimates.


Data Dictionary, Metadata, Years Available

Years Available: Annual estimates available 2005 onward; 5-year estimates available 2009 onward.
Geography: Nation, Region, Division, State, County, Census Tracts, Block Groups
Population: United States
Documentation: https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/acs/geography-acs/reference-materials.html



How to access
Reach out to bedacprp@bu.edu to request a dataset. Please specify years and geographies needed. We can help consult on tables needed, or investigators may select tables from the following link: https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/acs/technical-documentation/table-shells.html


Getting started

Handbooks for data users: https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/acs/library/handbooks.html
Technical Documentation: https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/acs/technical-documentation.html

title: Boston Biorepository, Recruitment, and Integrative Network (BBRAIN)
text:
The Boston Biorepository, Recruitment, and Integrative Network (BBRAIN) is a national research resource created to advance the study of Gulf War Illness (GWI), a chronic multisymptom condition affecting veterans of the 1990–91 Gulf War. GWI presents with persistent symptoms such as fatigue, pain, cognitive dysfunction, gastrointestinal issues, respiratory problems, and skin abnormalities. Because diagnosis has historically relied on self-reported symptoms and lacks validated biological markers, the field has been limited by fragmented datasets, small samples, inconsistent measurement, and difficulty validating findings across studies. BBRAIN was created to address these barriers by establishing a centralized biorepository and integrated data network designed to support large-scale, harmonized, and reproducible GWI research.

Keating et al. describes BBRAIN in detail, summarized below:
BBRAIN includes:

a formal data and biospecimen access system
an online request form
a steering committee review process
standardized operating procedures for data sharing and sample handling


Data Dictionary, Metadata, Years Available
BBRAIN places significant emphasis on data harmonization through the use of Common Data Elements (CDEs). These CDEs standardize how symptom questions, exposures, clinical assessments, and other variables are measured and recorded, enabling datasets from different studies and institutions to be combined more easily and reliably. By harmonizing these variables, BBRAIN reduces inconsistencies and enhances opportunities for replication, meta-analysis, biomarker discovery, and validation studies. This effort represents a major step forward for the GWI field, which has historically struggled with inconsistent measures and incompatible datasets.
The network also provides structured processes for data and biospecimen access. Researchers can apply to access BBRAIN materials through a centralized request system. Each request is reviewed by a steering committee to ensure scientific rigor and appropriate use of resources. The infrastructure includes governance structures, documentation standards, protocols for storing and transferring biospecimens, and processes for monitoring scientific output. The article notes that the biorepository and dataset merging infrastructure were already established at the time of publication, and retrospective datasets had been successfully combined.


How to access
Reach out to bedacprp@bu.edu

title: Research Environments
text:
This table summarizes key computing and data hosting environments available to BU-affiliated researchers working with sensitive, large-scale, or high-complexity data.









Resource
Description
Key Features
Limitations




BU Shared Computing Cluster (SCC)
High-performance computing (HPC) system supporting large-scale data processing and modeling
Thousands of CPU cores, GPU nodes, parallel computing, genomics/claims analysis support
Steep learning curve for non-technical users; some limitations on sensitive data storage


BMC CDW-R (BMC EHR)
De-identified and limited datasets from BMC’s Epic EHR, optimized for research with underserved populations
Clinical, demographic, encounter-level data; equity-focused use cases
Typical EHR issues (e.g., missing data, variable coding); may not generalize beyond BMC patients


BEDAC Secure Research Cloud (SRC)
HIPAA-compliant, access-controlled cloud for working with sensitive health data
Secure environment for EHR/claims data; tools include R, SAS, Python, SQL
Requires IRB & DUA approvals; onboarding time; limited to approved users

title: ARCH
text:
Copied from https://www.alzheimers.gov/taking-action/national-research-centers:
Originally established in 1984, the Alzheimer’s Disease Research Centers (ADRCs) are Congressionally designated Centers of Excellence. The ADRCs support the nation’s increased effort to address Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and Alzheimer’s disease-related dementias (ADRD) by providing information, local resources, support, and opportunities to participate in research. These centers are dedicated to developing and testing new ways to detect, diagnose, treat, and prevent dementia and to improving care for people with these diseases and their families. NIA and NIH fund ADRCs at research institutions across the United States. Each Center has a specific theme based on local populations and scientific areas of interest.
The ADRC program prioritizes collaboration and communication, as well as sharing resources, approaches, and results among centers and to outside researchers. By working collaboratively, the ADRCs have made significant contributions to addressing AD and ADRD.
For families affected by Alzheimer’s and related dementias, ADRCs offer:
Help with obtaining diagnosis and managing care for persons living with dementia Information about the diseases, new research findings, services, and resources Opportunities to learn about active clinical trials and participate in research studies that contribute to improved understanding of dementia, which may lead to new treatments and better care Support groups and other special programs for volunteers and their families Opportunity to obtain an autopsy at end of life, with a report provided to the family The History of Alzheimer’s Disease Research Centers The main objectives of the ADRCs program are to:
Conduct cutting-edge basic, clinical, and translational research and provide resources and infrastructure to address AD and ADRD Research Implementation Milestones Train the next generation of researchers in an environment that supports interactions across scientific disciplines Provide information to the public about research findings, access to support services, and opportunities to participate in research How Alzheimer’s Disease Research Centers Advance Research ADRCs conduct research spanning from the causes of and risk factors for AD and ADRD to potential treatments to managing symptoms and helping families cope. Center activities include:
Clinical Research: ADRCs each have a “Clinical Core” of research volunteers who come to the ADRC annually as part of a long-term study of aging and the brain. Volunteers complete annual tests and assessments that help researchers gather invaluable data to explore innovative approaches to diagnosis, treatment, and disease prevention. Outreach, Recruitment and Engagement: Each of the centers supports robust efforts to help raise awareness of AD and ADRD, inform the public about the latest research, support families, and recruit people to participate in research. ADRCs have created community programs, support groups, and informational materials. Centers recruit volunteers from their local community with a focus on populations that are understudied and/or are at higher risk for AD/ADRD to participate in research. To facilitate knowledge sharing across centers and with the wider dementia research community, many resources are available through the NIA-supported Alzheimer’s and Dementia Outreach, Recruitment, and Engagement (ADORE) repository. Data Sharing: Data collection and sharing helps researchers better understand diseases and develop effective treatment and prevention strategies. ADRCs share data and samples with a number of connected AD and ADRD repositories. The National Alzheimer’s Coordinating Center collects standardized data from all of the ADRCs and shares deidentified data with other qualified investigators. The ADRCs also send biological samples to the National Centralized Repository for Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias, genetic information to the Alzheimer’s Disease Genetics Consortium, and brain scans to the Standardized Centralized Alzheimer’s and Related Dementias Neuroimaging. These large-scale data sharing efforts enable researchers to make discoveries that would not be possible with smaller sample sizes. Much of the important progress in Alzheimer’s and other dementia research in the United States during the past 40 years stems from research conducted at — or with the help of resources provided by — the ADRCs. For example, ADRC researchers have:
Conducted a significant amount of the research on the processes behind amyloid plaque and tau tangle formation in the brain, which are hallmarks of Alzheimer’s disease. Characterized abnormal proteins associated with several different neurodegenerative diseases. Evaluated cognitive changes associated with normal aging and the transitions from early difficulties thinking and remembering to dementia. Identified factors that contribute to changes in cognitive abilities, such as social and physical activity. Related changes in brain structure to the clinical stages of Alzheimer’s using information gathered from participants during cognitive tests and assessments, brain imaging scans, and autopsies of donated brains. Helped to define a newly described type of dementia, Limbic-Predominant Age-Related TDP-43 Encephalopathy (LATE)

title: MarketScan
text:
MarketScan is a proprietary claims dataset that provides longitudinal patient-level data on healthcare utilization, expenditures, and outcomes. It includes data from commercial insurance plans, Medicare, and Medicaid populations across the United States. The dataset is widely used in health economics, pharmacoepidemiology, and outcomes research.


Data Dictionary, Metadata, Years Available

Years Available: 2006-2023
Population: Insured individuals in the U.S. covered by employer-sponsored private health insurance plans, including active employees, early retirees, COBRA continuers, and dependents.

Geography: State-level information across U.S.
Unit of analysis: Medical claim.
Documentation:

Download Data Dictionary (PDF)
Download User Guide (PDF)




Data Use Agreement (DUA) and Abstract
Access to MarketScan data is governed by a Data Use Agreement (DUA) between Truven Health Analytics and Boston University. Please contact the Data Steward (email below) for more information.
Sample abstract for DUA request: > This project aims to examine the impact of medication adherence on hospitalization rates among patients with chronic conditions using MarketScan Commercial Claims and Encounters data from 2015–2021.


Common Use Cases

Health services research analyzing healthcare utilization, costs, and outcomes.
Epidemiology and disease burden studies in privately insured populations.
Outcomes research involving chronic conditions, surgical procedures, and preventive services



Related Publications

Podolsky MI, Raquib R, Shafer PR, Hempstead K, Ellis RP, Stokes AC. Factors Associated With Semaglutide Initiation Among Adults With Obesity. JAMA Netw Open. 2025 Jan 2;8(1):e2455222. doi: 10.1001/jamanetworkopen.2024.55222. PMID: 39836425; PMCID: PMC11751746.



Code Snippets to Get Started
# Load claims data
claims <- fread("marketscan_claims_2021.csv")

# Summary by diagnosis
claims[, .N, by = .(diagnosis_code)][order(-N)]

# Join with enrollment data
merged <- merge(claims, enrollment, by = "patient_id")

title: CDC Platforms (WONDER, mRFEI, PLACES, and related systems)
text:
CDC Platforms (WONDER, mRFEI, PLACES, and related systems)
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) maintains a suite of publicly accessible data platforms that provide authoritative, policy-relevant health, environmental, and demographic information for population health research and surveillance. These platforms offer standardized, high-quality datasets covering topics such as mortality, chronic disease, health behaviors, environmental exposures, healthcare resources, and social determinants of health. Key systems include:
CDC WONDER (Wide-ranging Online Data for Epidemiologic Research)
A flagship query system providing access to numerous national datasets, including mortality records, natality data, cancer registries, infectious disease reports, population estimates, environmental exposures, and census-linked indicators. WONDER supports custom tabulations, age adjustment, stratification, and export, making it widely used for descriptive epidemiology and trend analyses.
mRFEI (Modified Retail Food Environment Index) A census-tract–level measure of the local retail food environment, summarizing the proportion of food retailers considered “healthy” (e.g., supermarkets, grocery stores) relative to all food retailers. mRFEI is commonly used in studies examining nutrition environments, food access, urban planning, and disparities in diet-related health outcomes.
PLACES (Population Level Analysis and Community Estimates) A collaboration between CDC, RWJF, and the Census Bureau that provides model-based estimates of chronic disease, risk factors, and preventive health measures for all U.S. counties, census tracts, and ZIP Code Tabulation Areas. PLACES covers metrics such as obesity, diabetes, high blood pressure, physical inactivity, smoking, mental health, and preventive screenings—making it valuable for small-area health surveillance and community health assessment.
Other related CDC open-data platforms Including systems such as the Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS) online tools, the National Environmental Public Health Tracking Network, the Social Vulnerability Index (SVI), and the 500 Cities/PLACES predecessor datasets. These platforms collectively offer multiscale, geographically resolved indicators on environment, health behaviors, chronic disease outcomes, and vulnerability.
Use Cases and Strengths
CDC platforms are widely used for:
Population health monitoring and small-area surveillance
Environmental health and climate-health research
Social determinants of health analyses
Policy evaluation and program planning
Epidemiologic trend and disparity analyses
Their advantages include national coverage, consistent methodology, annual updates for many indicators, and easy access for researchers, policymakers, and community organizations.

title: DataAxle
text:
Data Axle provides comprehensive business and consumer data that includes millions of U.S. business records, categorized by industry using enhanced NAICS and SIC codes. These data enable granular analysis of resource access and utilization at geographic resolutions as small as the Census Block. Data are updated annually and include information about site, employee size and revenue.


Data Dictionary, Metadata, Years Available

Years Available: 1997-2024
Geography: Geocoded point-of-interest data
Population: United States
Documentation:

Tutorial from BU Libraries: https://library.bu.edu/dataaxle




How to access
Reach out to bedacprp@bu.edu to request a dataset designated by: - Year - Business code (NAICS, SIC) - Zip code (optional) - State (optional) - Location or parent employee size (optional) - Location or parent sales volume code (optional) - Gender of contact or executive (optional)


Related Publications

Nori-Sarma A, Spangler KR, Wang B, Cesare N, Dukes KA, Lane KJ. Impacts of the choice of distance measurement method on estimates of access to point-based resources. J Expo Sci Environ Epidemiol. 2023 Mar;33(2):237-243. doi: 10.1038/s41370-022-00414-z. Epub 2022 Feb 10. PMID: 35145207.



Getting started

Download Getting Started Guide (.pptx)

title: URBAN ARCH
text:
URBAN ARCH maintains a [data repository[(https://sites.bu.edu/urbanarch/resources/data-sample-repository/) that provides detailed information on all available datasets. The full catalog is accessible through the project’s website.
Years Available 2012–2022
Population The URBAN ARCH consortium includes three cohorts of people living with HIV in Mbarara, Uganda; St. Petersburg, Russia; and Boston, Massachusetts. Research across these sites focuses primarily on alcohol and substance use and their effects on HIV disease progression, along with a range of other clinical and behavioral outcomes.
Access The repository is restricted-access. Investigators must request permission to obtain datasets.
Notes and Considerations
The three cohorts differ substantially in demographic and behavioral characteristics, and many investigators focus on analyses within a single cohort.
Cross-cohort analyses are possible but often challenging to justify. For example, substance-use patterns differ dramatically across sites (e.g., minimal drug use in Uganda versus predominantly injection-drug use in the Russia cohort).
Several available datasets originate from clinical trials.

How to access
Reach out to bedacprp@bu.edu

title: ADVANCE / OCHIN
text:
From advancecollaborative.org/data-warehouse:
The ADVANCE Data Warehouse (DW) is the nation’s largest and most comprehensive database on community-based health care and outcomes, representing over 14 million patients nationwide. As the single largest source of primary care data within PCORnet®, ADVANCE combines electronic health records (EHR) using the PCORnet® Common Data Model, a standardized, research-ready format designed for scalable, multi-site studies. This shared Common Data Model makes varied types of data, including demographics, vital signs, labs, clinical observations, diagnoses, and more, available for research across a diverse and expansive set of participating sites.
Data offerings include:
ADVANCE Research Overview is a high-level summary of the ADVANCE Clinical Research Network (CRN), ideal for investigators interested in project collaboration.
ADVANCE and OCHIN Data Dictionary and User Guide provides in-depth details on the data domains, tables, and variables available for research within the ADVANCE CRN.

Publications
Boone-Heinonen, Janne, Carrie J. Tillotson, Jean P. O’Malley, Miguel Marino, Sarah B. Andrea, Andrew Brickman, Jennifer DeVoe, and Jon Puro. “Not so implausible: impact of longitudinal assessment of implausible anthropometric measures on obesity prevalence and weight change in children and adolescents.” Annals of epidemiology 31 (2019): 69-74. link


How to access
Reach out to bedacprp@bu.edu

title: Acumen CMS Data Linkage (NIA)
text:
From https://www.nia.nih.gov/research/dbsr/nia-data-linkage-program-linkage and https://www.nia.nih.gov/research/dbsr/nia-data-linkage-program-linkage/available-data
This dataset links Medicare claims to several major NIA-funded longitudinal studies of aging, including the Health and Retirement Study (HRS) and the National Health and Aging Trends Study (NHATS). By combining detailed survey-based measures with comprehensive Medicare administrative data, it enables robust longitudinal analyses of older adults’ health trajectories, healthcare utilization, spending patterns, and clinical outcomes.
The data are curated and managed by Acumen LLC, which maintains high-quality, research-ready linked files across cohorts. These linked datasets support a wide range of aging, health services, and policy research applications, particularly those requiring validated clinical outcomes, multi-year follow-up, and rich person-level covariates.
CMS data available in LINKAGE The LINKAGE Program offers the following CMS data:
Raw CMS claims data:
Longitudinal datasets that fully track beneficiaries across time. File layout alignments enabled to streamline programming. Granular health care service details that allow for robust analyses. CMS data sets and years of data available, include:
Medicare Parts A and B: 1991 - 2024 Medicare Part C: 2015 - 2023 Medicare Part D: 2006 - 2024 Medicare Assessment Data: 1999- 2023 Medicare Enrollment Data: 1991 – 2024 Medicaid Data: 1999 – 2023 Learn about the CMS data available by downloading the NIA CMS Data Dictionary (Excel, 600K).
LINKAGE Medicare and Medicaid Summary Files (LMMSF):
Comprehensive medical and health histories summarized at the beneficiary-level. Constructed in a wide-format to see a beneficiary’s healthcare journey in a file with one line per beneficiary with columns for years available. LLMSF files are available for the following NIA-funded Studies in the LINKAGE enclave: * Health and Retirement Study (HRS) * National Health and Aging Trends Study (NHATS) * Rush Alzheimer’s Disease Center (RADC) * Understanding America Study (UAS)
The LMMSF can be requested as a separate file through the NIA DUA process in the LINKAGE DOCS Portal.
Below you can view NIA-funded studies that are currently linked to CMS data in the NIA Data LINKAGE Program.
Note: Researchers seeking a linked-dataset from one of the following studies, must contact the Study first to seek approval through each Study’s DUA process before seeking access to the LINKAGE Program.
Application of Economics & Social Psychology to Improve Opioid Prescribing Safety (AESOPS) Trial: The AESOPS trial’s objectives are to discourage unnecessary opioid prescribing through the application of “behavioral insights”-empirically-tested social and psychological interventions that affect choice.
Advanced Cognitive Training for Independent and Vital Elderly (ACTIVE): Established in 1998, ACTIVE is the largest study on cognitive training. The ACTIVE study proves that healthy older adults can make significant cognitive improvements with appropriate cognitive training and practice.
Boston Early Adversity & Mortality Study (BEAMS): BEAMS brings together diverse data to provide a comprehensive picture on the early life conditions of persons who were born in the late 19th and early 20th century and have been studied closely for most of their lives.
Health and Retirement Study (HRS): Starting in 1992, HRS is a longitudinal panel study that explores the changes in labor force participation and the health transitions that individuals undergo toward the end of their work lives and in the years that follow. Visit HRS’ site for instructions on how to access HRS data.
LONG LIFE Family Study (LLFS): Established in 2005, LLFS is an international collaborative study of the genetics and familial components of exceptional survival, longevity, and healthy aging.
Long-Term Care Data (LTC) Cooperative: The LTC Data Cooperative seeks “to improve the quality of care within post-acute and long-term care facilities by compiling the most comprehensive data on post-acute and long-term care residents nationwide – and to translate these data into accessible and actionable information designed to help clinicians, managers and policy makers improve care”.
Long-term Effects of a Community-based Volunteer Trial on Lifestyle Activity and Risk for Alzheimer’s Disease (ExpCorps): ExCorps seeks to determine whether increased social, physical and cognitive engagement leads to long-term lower risk for Alzheimer’s disease, reductions in healthcare expenditures, maintained functional independence, improved quality of life, less disability and lower mortality.
Midlife in the United States (MIDUS): Established in 1995, the MIDUS study “was conceived by scientists from diverse fields who were interested in how physical and mental health changes across the decades of adult life, for whom, and why.”
National Dementia Workforce Study (NDWS): Established in 2023, NDWS fields the first large, nationally representative surveys of the professional dementia care workforce in the United States, including community clinicians, and nursing home, assisted living, and home care staff and administrators.
National Health & Aging Trends Study (NHATS): Starting in 2011, NHATS fosters research to guide efforts to reduce disability, maximize health and independent functioning, and enhance quality of life at older age.
National Long Term Care Survey (NLTCS): Beginning in 1982, NLTCS is a longitudinal survey designed to study changes in the health and functional status of older Americans. It also tracks health expenditures, Medicare service use, and more.
Optimizing Electronic Health Record Prompts with Behavioral Economics to Improve (NUDGE-EHR): Established in 2020, NUDGE-EHR is a 16-arm adaptive randomized pragmatic trial to evaluate whether designing electronic health record (EHR)-based tools using behavioral science principles reduces inappropriate prescribing and clinical outcomes in older adults.
Panel Study of Income Dynamics (PSID): Beginning in 1968, PSID is the longest running longitudinal household survey that measures economic and social well-being and has allowed researchers and policy analysts to investigate the dynamism inherent in social and behavioral processes.

Rush Alzheimer’s Disease Center (RADC): Established in 1997, RADC is committed to discovering better ways to diagnose, treat, and prevent Alzheimer’s and other dementias. Understanding America Study (UAS): Founded in 2014, UAS has created an in-depth portrayal of the people in the United States including their cognitive abilities, financial views, retirement planning, and well-being.
Understanding Cohort Effects on Stroke, VCID, and Cognition After Major Epidemiologic Transitions (Formerly: The REasons for Geographic And Racial Difference in Stroke (REGARDS) study): Started in 2003, REGARDS is an ongoing, national cohort study that has followed its participants to understand why Southerners and Black Americans have higher rates of stroke and related diseases that affect brain health.
Wisconsin Longitudinal Study (WLS): Established in 1957, WLS is a long-term study that collects data on family functioning, intergenerational transfers, intergenerational relationships, life course, morbidity, mortality, physical health, mental health, and well-being.
